feed.title: Combined summary - Mining centralization pressure from non-uniform propagation speed

entry.title: Combined summary - Mining centralization pressure from non-uniform propagation speed
entry.summary: Pieter Wuille, a Bitcoin Core developer, has created a simulator for Bitcoin mining which goes beyond the one Gavin Andresen used in his blog post. The main difference is support for links with different latency and bandwidth, because of the clustered configuration described below. The simulation involves two groups of miners (one 80%=25%+25%+30%, one 20%=5%+5%+5%+5%), which are well-connected internally, but are only connected to each other through a slow 2 Mbit/s link. When fees become more important however, and half of a block's income is due to fees, the effect becomes even stronger (a 15% loss), and the optimal way to compete for small miners is to create larger blocks as well (smaller blocks for them result in even less income).In a discussion between Pieter Wuille and Jonas Nick, Pieter suggests that larger blocks lead to centralization pressure in the system. Jonas responds by pointing out that in Pieter's scenario, where big miners are part of the majority partition, it is unclear whether the pressure to merge with big miners can be separated from the pressure to connect with the majority partition. To test this, Jonas runs a simulation with a large miner in a 20% minority partition and 16 small miners in an 80% majority partition; to increase realism, the simulation includes a "slow link" speed of 100 Mbit/s.Pieter Wuille has created a Bitcoin mining simulator which takes into account various variables such as block sizes, fees, processing and mining delays, difficulty adjustments, and simulates longer periods of time. It also averages the result of many simulations running in parallel until the variance on the result is low enough. The code is available on GitHub.The results of the simulation show that making small blocks when others are making big ones is bad, and fees become enormous. Being separated by a slow link from the majority hash power is also bad. However, being a small miner with blocksize=20MB is not bad. The simulation uses four different configurations which demonstrate the effects of block size and fee per byte on the income of two miner groups with different hashrates.The context explains that two entities are connected to each other through a slow 2 Mbit/s link. This speed is much slower than the average 3G connection, which can reach speeds of 7-8 Mbit/sec. The simulation being discussed assumes a speed even worse than what a mobile phone can achieve, indicating a significant limitation in the connectivity between the two entities.Additionally, there are emails exchanged between Mike Hearn and an unnamed author discussing the impact of a per-node imposed max block size limit and the slow speed of a 2 Mbit/s link between two connected entities. The email exchange between Pieter and Gavin Andresen discusses the simulation of bandwidth for block messages as a bottleneck, and also the potential advantage for miners to sabotage the relay network. Tom Harding's email thread with Pieter discusses the effects of block size on centralization pressure in the Bitcoin system, while Peter Todd and Gavin Andresen discuss the benefits of producing larger, more-fee blocks that propagate slowly and including high-fee transactions.Overall, Pieter Wuille's simulator shows the effects of larger blocks on centralization pressure in the system, without making any assumption of destructive behavior on the network - just simple profit maximization.
